properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement:
I’m a lifelong writer and poet who has also worked professionally as high school
teacher, print journalist, network television story editor, and museum curator. My
unwavering conviction about the importance of our human connection to each other
and to the environment we share with all life on Earth, is central to my poetry and
writing.

When I first arrived in Silicon Valley thirty-eight years ago, I wanted to explore its
less urban as well as its burgeoning urban spaces. On weekends we often broke
free to travel backroads and byways that still resonated with vestiges of the earlier
residents, wildlife, vegetation and waterways that defined them. These day-trips
reinforced a robust sense of the relationship of people to the land they live, work,
and die upon.

Visits to national parks and designated open spaces across the U.S., and national
parks in other countries, inspire with their ongoing presence and accessibility the
preservation of open spaces, despite threats to reduce their acreage for commerce.
In the same spirit, Santa Clara County and multiple adjacent county parks attract
visitors to picnic, hike, fish, and enjoy nature. They also provide local opportunities
for respite and remembering.

Some occupations of previously rural spaces are now noticeably in transition, and
might eventually give way to urban expansion. Maybe this is all the more reason to
impart an awareness of past ways of being here into future memory—a charm
against forgetting not only what has gone before, but protection today against
over-development of living, breathing land.

San Jose is a cutting edge theater of technology for which we can be justly proud.
I’m happily here to also celebrate some of its less obvious “under-stories” as part of
an ongoing, land-based history of place we call home.

properties.title of work: Backroads and Byways of San Jose

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement:
I am from faces I do not recognize 
And tongues I cannot speak
From the writings of Sui Sin Far, 
Of both the far and middle East
I am from ballads of kingdoms, oriental dreams
And histories lost, that tie together all things

I am from the California gold mines deep within the earth, 
Where rough-hewn hands work in rhythm
With the clashes of metal and whistling steam
My pó po, wading in rice paddies, hearing war planes fly overhead
The smell of orchid and jasmine, or pungent tang of dry herbs,
Wafting through old dormitories on Angel Island

I am from the pogroms of Eastern Europe (Poland, Ukraine, I can’t be sure)
That left our blood and names muddled, wrapped with
Patterned cloth for safekeeping in the journey ahead
Hushed coven meetings of swarthy women, with
Their yiddish etched, sizzling, in the kitchen air
Woven with familiar taste of pickled goods and warm bread

I am from Michigan’s cast-iron sky, whose harsh
Snow is as soft as Ezekiel Solomon’s furs
Where a sculpture of my grandmother sings out to me 
In her bronze song, high and lonely across the years
Faint, like the perfume that lingers on her scarves
Musky and sweet as it clings to the skin

I am from the heat of the last apricot orchard in bloom
The bitterness of hard, unripened fruit
From the smell of lanolin and dog’s fur, wet from the rain
That pitter-patters the mossy roof while I sleep 
Soothed by the mourning dove’s call
I am here, I am here

I am from words I can’t pronounce
And names with several iterations
Conjured by unseen mitzvahs 
and old-world superstition
I am from the end
But also the beginning

properties.bio url: Tessa (b. 1993) was raised, and currently resides, in the California Bay Area where she received her Bachelors of Fine Arts and Associates in Art History. As an alum of SJSU she continues to pursue her passion for illustration, printmaking, and writing. Her work focuses on exploring her deep love of the natural world as well as the complexities of self-identity within queer and bi-racial communities.

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement:
110 Rio Robles, San Jose is the site which occupied most of my hours when I became officially diagnosed with “migraines with photophobia.” At the time I was very perplexed. I didn’t know how aches in my eyeballs counted as migraines. After leaving the company I went on a three-month break from computers, thinking that would fix my issue (I only got headaches when looking at computer screens) but when I slowly returned to the virtual world, I found my light-tolerance grinding down. Later I set up a lunch date (also in San Jose)  with the same co-worker who read my palm; he asked me, “You’re better now, right?” only to be surprised with the unfortunate truth. But this was only the beginning of a long and arduous saga of learning to live with a disability—one that even my doctors struggled to assist me with (my last two neurologists ejected me from their practices, citing that my condition was atypical and they couldn’t help me anymore). 

Because of my disability, San Jose has been my home for the last several years. I had plans of graduate school, even flying out to scope out programs, but those drowned under the tide of new health-related problems.  Sometimes I feel ashamed about not having “overcome” like many other people with disabilities have, but, eh, each has their own journey. At least, despite the fluctuating landscape of my health, one thing has remained steadfast—my love for writing. The truest change is how I put the words on the page. So here I am, finding power and grace amidst the light.
properties.I confirm that I am over the age of 18 a: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.bio url: L.D. Nguyen lives inside of comic books but frequently emerges from this 2-D universe to write short fiction and creative nonfiction, primarily about gender and sexuality. Her zodiac animal is the wood horse, which are allegedly good at self-deprecating humor. For three years she typed her material blind because of her severe light-sensitivity, and she continues to write mostly blind due to headaches from eye-movement. Her work has appeared in New Haven Review, Broken Pencil, Litro, Curve, and others. She lives in the Bay Area, California with her cat.

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement: As a writer, I want to contribute to the healing of the human heart.  As a catholic woman, my heart is healed in my writings as I believe my pieces are the homilies I had to hold silent.  I was nervous in writing this piece as I have never experienced racism.  I am interested however in how xenophobia gets buried and disappeared in those of us second and third generation immigrant kids who are white and will never know the lived and bled struggles of our BIPOC neighbors and loved ones.  I believe it is my duty and I know it is my great joy to live and write with what poet Galway Kinnell calls, “a tenderness towards existence.”

properties.location: Five Wounds neighborhood, East San Jose, Cambrian neighborhood of San Jose, California
properties.bio url: Michelle S. Myers is a bilingual psychotherapist, originally from and currently living with her faithful terrier mix Perry Berry Benicio Myers in the Valley of the heart’s delight, San José, California.  Brought up a left-leaning catholic, Myers no longer is waiting for Rome to wake up to women’s ordination, but has decided to go ahead on her own, and ordain the women around her who are spiritual writers, teachers, leaders, activists, and mystics.  She was very influenced by the Jesuit principles of God in all things and social justice in her formative years which led her to travel, volunteer in, and live in Latin America for many years.  Myers finally learned Portuguese during her four years as a Maryknoller in São Paulo, Brazil.  After a time of working in community mental health and advocacy for immigrants, Michelle now works in private practice and is thrilled to occasionally commune with the writers of her Friday morning writing group led by professor, poet, and novelist, Lita Kurth.
properties.text submission:
I survived 2020 hanging out in my dear friend’s backyard under her Mulberry tree and solar-powered blinky lights, her husband serving us his excellent margaritas. She’s a sociology professor and I’m a shrink, thus we ramble, but profoundly so.  We discuss relationships, podcasts, and we also consider housing, work, feminism, and xenophobia in our San Jose.  San Jose was under our micro and macro analyses this year as we stayed home divided;  not hugging, not having birthday parties, not knowing what was coming next.  

Since I’m part Portuguese, my friend later sends me part of these macro studies — a multicolored map of San Jose from 1937.  She’s been introduced some to the Santa Clara Portuguese community with their interminable masses and train-laden gowned Portuguese princesses at her church.   The brightly colored apparently cheerful map is interpreted by Mapping Inequality— published with commentary from home loan officials who sliced and diced San Jose according to color, class, immigration, and ancestry.  “Hazerdous” communities in the San Jose of 1937 included African-Americans, Japanese immigrant communities, Mexican immigrants, and Portuguese immigrants.  “You should really look at these,” my friend says, referring to quadrant D-9 in red which describes its inhabitants as “an infiltration of low-class Portuguese, Mexicans, and negroes.” 

I suddenly imagine me, and the dignitaries; UFW co-founder Cesar Chavez, and our nation’s poet laureate, Amanda Gorman standing in that undesirable red quadrant (very east from where I grew up in the Cambrian neighborhood — now often referred to as Willow Glen by real estate agents) near 26th street and East Santa Clara.  I’m the only one of us three in my fantasy who could potentially hopscotch out of the undesirable red square within a generation.  Sal si puedes— “get out if you can” — only facilitated with my white skin.  White skin —doing nothing but being white —trumping even Gorman’s exquisite mastery of words brought to life with her free-bird hands and harmony of inflections, and even Chavez’s saintly courage and lifetime devotion to convincing the powers that be that people need to be treated as human beings.  In this English-speaking whiteness, I never knew I was part Portuguese until I was about 15.  I remember asking my grandpa about my grandma’s vinha de alhos dish, and he— hiding his Lithuanian Ashkenazi roots (even to his death)— laughed, “Hey, be sure you don’t marry a portagee!”  

My mother, an Irish-Dutch-American nurse of Montana copper mining roots, got our family  involved in our church’s devotion to Chavez and Huerta’s Si se puede movement.  The newborns of Central Valley farm workers were being deformed by big agriculture’s pesticides, and so my brothers and I never ate grapes in our childhood.  I still feel guilty if I eat them now.  I always knew the Irish were boisterous, and that the Italian side of me allowed for homemade raviolis at Christmastime.  But the Portuguese part remained a mystery to me, hidden in the inheritance of this “low-class” status that my grandma was determined to make invisible under her French glass, British flatware, and American patriotic pride.  My mother, following Chavez’s strike, brought to the heart of our kitchen table the inequities that she wanted to teach us were social sin— even down in our tastebuds.  Stratification gets cuttingly sharp close up.  

Like most Portuguese in San Jose, I’m Azorean.  My grandma was raised by her grandma, Ana Mattos who hailed from lush Faial, one of the rural farming and fishing communities in this string of nine islands.  It’s about three hours flying out into the blue Atlantic abyss from Lisbon.  Although now a hipster vacation destination, the Azores are their own kind of “definitely declining” D-9 red-lined community east adjacent to mainland Europe’s prestige.  Outside of the quadrants of racism, they are stunning island paradises full of resilient Azoreans.  My grandma, born in 1916 did not gift me with her ability to speak Portuguese, nor approve of my parent’s Catholic Church which stood in solidarity with Mexicans — she was all too aware of the dangers of revealing those dividing lines emphasized on that 1937 map decoded by my sociology professor friend and Mapping Inequality. My grandma, Eva Alberta Mattos Landucci made sure to erase all those beautiful “low-class” vowels in her name, shook that red line from her body, and shielded by her white skin, buried any traces of color that would deteriorate her children’s and grandchildren’s cultural capital.

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement:
I’m from the smell of frozen laundry and long-expected summer storm,
And strong yet subtle lilac fragrance and oily scent of train platform,
The smell of mama’s tart sharlotka1 and stable’s pungent earthy tone.
I’m from nasturtium’s sharp aroma and stifling fumes of acetone.

I’m from the taste of tea with lemon and freshly fallen fluffy snow,
And sweet frost-bitten rowanberry that last I ate so long ago.
I’m from the taste of fried potatoes and sea buckthorn delicious mors2,
And sugar snap pea from the garden and dark rye bread both soft and coarse.

I’m from the sound of roaring thunder and gentle hum of bass guitar,
And from the power of orchestra and train that’s rumbling from afar.
I’m from my papa’s vibrant sneezes, from snow that crunches under boot,
And from the cuckoo’s measured chuckle and tragic ballad of a lute.

I’m from the ancient Ural Mountains from biggest country in the world.
I’m from the books I’ve read, and stories that I was once, in secret, told.
I’m from the quiet podvorotni3, from places filled with buzz and din.
I’m from the past, I’m from the future, I am from all that’s ever been.

________________________
1.	Шарлотка (Rus /sharlotka) – apple pie
2.	Морс (Rus /mors)– a simple drink made by mixing jam and water
3.	Подворотни (Rus /podvorotni)– archways in walls of multistory residential buildings, providing car access to inner court

properties.hashtag: Californio, Spanish-Mexican, Anza, Berryessa, Bernal, Almaden, quicksilver
properties.statement: For the last thirty years Zacarías’s history and mine have shared the same league of land in the Almaden Valley, but I felt her presence there long before I "met" her. Discovering what had happened right under my feet explained much of what I had sensed, and infused me with an urgent need to spread the word. It also put my own mid-life crises into perspective, and gave me a worthy focus at a difficult time. It's been a privilege to learn and write about this courageous, remarkable woman, and to share her story through MINE.

properties.bio url: Jenny Clendenen is a native Bay Area writer whose essays, scholarship, and poetry have appeared in a variety of venues, from BBC Travel to Studies in Philology. She has a BA in English literature and an MFA in creative nonfiction from San Jose State University.

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement:
I am from

the smell of spent coffee grounds, 
machine oil, ink, peanuts, and sambal
office chairs, instant cocoa, a fax machine

the taste of milk, orange khichuri, and soft oats

the sound of dub, beats, and breaks
typing and clicking, papers folding and flipping
doyal Nitai, bells, and tides

now including but not limited to
Tjilatjap, Indonesia, and war(s); Amsterdam, Netherlands; Elgg
hand painted Texas signs hot on armadillo go go juice; El Saba
Aptos, Santa Cruz County, California, United States of America
36º 59’ 22” North
121º 58’ 55” West 

deva-bhūmiḥ, mahat-tattva, and tatastha-loka
just a hop, skip, and jump from the soul plane

properties.bio url: Alexander Werdmuller von Elgg has been a visual artist his whole life and his artwork primarily focuses on graphite and ink drawings on paper. His visual language includes representational renderings and non-objective abstractions. Alexander looks for the observable harmonies of lines, shapes, and value in the two dimensional format; hence, he often looks to music for inspiration and analogies to bring into his visual art.

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement:
I am from a song that no one else can hear,
an echo of a memory
that has long since frayed
where there are no more strands left to grasp,
except for the cold metal in my palm
チャリン  チャリン

I am from the taste of lukewarm coffee left unfinished,
bitter yet sweet, new yet familiar,
much like every farewell
where something raw and heavy rises in my throat
and I swallow it back down into the recesses of my chest
チャリン  チャリン

I am from the sound of the ever turning pages of a notebook
where it fills up as two timelines pass me by,
in the sepia-colored distance my grandfather sits at a desk,
counting his coins at the table
as if depositing them into an unseen box
チャリン  チャリン

I am from the water
where my ancestors' dreams collided
and my unwritten story began,
the offerings from my grandfather
ringing in my ears
チャリン  チャリン

She enjoy learning a variety of techniques and skills to further her artmaking process, mixing them with her knowledge of web development and design to showcase a variety of concepts.

properties.statement: This poem came from the feeling I get whenever driving south to downtown San Jose in the winter, that we experience winter in a different way than people do in places that have more definitive seasons.

properties.bio url: A graphic artist and lifelong poet, Stephanie Pressman earned an MA in English from San Jose State University, taught writing at community college, and is the editor of her small press, Frog on the Moon. She served as co-editor of cæsura and americas review. Her work has appeared in Bridges, The MacGuffin, The Kerf, Sing Heavenly Muse, and Montserrat Review as well as on-line in Newport Review, Halfway Down the Stairs, Red Wolf Editions, Ekphrastic Review, The Collidescope, and others. Her long poem Lovebirdman appears in an illustrated volume published in June, 2018.

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement: On the morning after my ninth birthday, I carried a cerise suitcase and left Sadec, Vietnam on a mythical journey that eventually led to San Jose’s Little Saigon, a land where traditional foods were cooked with slightly different ingredients and where the people spoke with newly adjusted tongues. No matter where I went, I was slightly out-of-place. And so it became, that out of the necessity to invent a place to belong, poetry found me. My poetic instincts were formed from the sights and sounds of those immigrant streets and the vibrations of roads and buildings that were both familiar and foreign. It is the poetry of a body and heart learning its new language in secrecy.
properties.I confirm that I am over the age of 18 a: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.bio url: From the Mekong Delta to the Tenderloin, Lê immigrated to San Francisco at the age of nine.  Lê holds an MFA in Creative Writing from San José State University. Her publications include Corridors (2001) and Little Sister Left Behind (2007). Her poetry has appeared in numerous literary journals, including: Bayou Magazine, Borderlands: Texas Poetry Review, Hypertrophic Literary, The Minnesota Review and The Suburban Review. Lê is currently working on A False Dawn, a poetry collection about the Vietnamese-American immigrant experience.
properties.text submission:
Đi Về (Little Saigon)

Immigrant road, a far-reaching whip, 
and me, returning to my origin with new skin 
to parade through that crowded cul-de-sac 
of adopted mothers, cousins, aunties 
(chị cả, bác, cô, dì, thím, mợ), 
in-laws, exes, sisters and grannies, 
who are all related in the mythical 
entanglement of họ hàng, 
and whom I’ve spent decades weeding 
from my carefully cultivated plot.
Not rootless but wanderer just the same
through the bloodline of dragons 
and immortal gods, born of the same womb
to the same familial bondage that binds 
as blindly as faith; how do I carry on 
when distant traditions keep me in my place?

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement: This poem is a meditation upon the variety of personal approaches to hiking in the foothills above Santa Clara Valley. It also features a variety of local flora and fauna. From the elevated perspective of the Cora Older Trail, the entire South Bay Area is visible. On a clear day, the hiker may enjoy a view of the bay and its bridges, as well as the local landmarks of Stanford University, NASA Research Center & Moffett Field, Mount Diablo, the Apple campus, Levi Stadium, the San Jose skyline, and the eastern foothills.

properties.bio url: David Denny is a poet and fiction writer living in Cupertino. Recent books include Sometimes Only the Sad Songs Will Do, Some Divine Commotion, The Gill Man in Purgatory, and Fool in the Attic. He is Professor of English at De Anza College and a recipient of an Artist Laureate Award from the Silicon Valley Arts Council.
properties.text submission:
David Denny

Hikers, Three Varieties

        after Jeffrey Harrison

There are those for whom the mountain is just 
one more fitness course made to work the quads 
and boost the heart rate. Once they hit the peak, 
they claim the view, comment on the weather, 
compare pedometers. They can’t stand still 
for long lest their muscles begin to cool and cramp. 
They can’t wait to descend, to arrive at the coffee shop 
in full regalia and check today’s trail off their list. 
For them, one switch-backed, fat-burning ascent 
may very well be mistaken for another.

And there are those for whom the hike is a social 
outing—a chance to walk their dogs and complain 
of their lot: their inattentive spouse, their burdensome 
children. When they finally stumble across the bench 
in the clearing, Fido straining at the leash, tongue 
lolling, they sit just long enough to water the animal and 
ready the plastic baggie for collection. They’ve missed 
the quail and white-tailed deer, the rattlesnake and 
painted ladies flittering among trailside thistles. 
No wild thought has intruded upon their day.

And then there are those lonesome fools for whom 
the trail is a listening post on the universe. Attuned to 
the daily office of blossom and rot, their ears are pricked up 
for mystery borne upon the liquid rustle of summer leaves. 
Their eyes wander towards the shadowy undergrowth, 
the wagging branch, the tremendous wings slicing 
across the sky. They break through at the startling peak 
just as the breeze’s lullaby chimes its final notes. 
Stalked by some divine commotion, they gaze 
over the fertile valley, speechless, attentive, still.

properties.statement: I moved to San Jose in my early 20s, fresh out of law school.  I used to take walks exploring downtown on my lunch breaks, feeling simultaneously at home in and intrigued by my new surroundings.  The delight in spotting a truck full of exotic fruit (to a Pennsylvania girl) was another example of the possibilities that lay before me in this town.
properties.I confirm that I am over the age of 18 a: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.text submission:
How to Steal an Avocado
(first published in Snail Mail Review, Issue 1, 2010)

Notice: someone has left
an avocado delivery truck 
parked just here on a San Jose street.

If no one is looking, kick off your stilettos, 
clamber up, sit cross-legged 
among the cardboard crates mounding with fruit.

From the corkscrew in your purse, fashion a blade
to breach the leathery skin, a tender little violence
for quick reward.

And there in the truck’s deep cool mouth, realize – 
you are not unlike these alligator pears
which could not ripen on the vine.

How lucky that once plucked free, they found you 
walking on a palm-lined avenue,
hungry.

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement:
I am from the smell of the morning dew and Plumeria
From 豆浆 (dòu jiāng) and 油条 (yóu tiáo)
From Sichuan pepper, cumin, star anise, and tangerine peel
I am from Chinese food
I am from the taste of the spicy hot pot
Mushroom, tofu bubble, and pickled pepper
Sweet potato noodles and tomato scrambled eggs
Corn soup always reminds me of my childhood
I am from the sounds of Mandarin and Cantonese in Guangdong
Zǎo Shàng Hǎo (早上好) and Zou San (早晨) 
is the beginning of my day
The wind traveling through the streets
From the sound of gears spinning on a clock
I am from a planet in the universe named Earth
I am from Luohu District, Shenzhen, China, and Asia
I am from the hearts of my best friends
I am from inside of my dreams 
where the places I can achieve all the adventures

properties.hashtag: History of Marginalized Communities in San Jose
properties.statement:
Parthenia M. Hicks
Artist’s Statement
San Jose Storyboard Project
May 2021


As a writer and poet, I believe it is my “job” to observe and describe what I see. “Peacock” describes a marginalized San Jose community by telling one story of prejudice culminating in carefully crafted and planned physical and emotional violence toward gay people at a particular time period within San Jose’s history. 

“Peacock” describes incidents that occurred in San Jose at the former Valley Fair Mall before it was demolished and replaced with the current mega-mall, Westfield. The story is told on behalf of the many voiceless gay men and women who lived in the area during the days when gay people were rounded up and hauled off to jail—the period just before and after the Stonewall Riots in Greenwich Village began to shift the oppressive view of gay-ness as criminal behavior. 

As the manager of what was then the largest bookshop in the South Bay, a two-level much-loved shop that served San Jose for many years, I personally, along with the bookshop staff witnessed the persecution of gay men who were “set up” by cops pretending to be gay in the men’s bathroom just outside the downstairs bookshop entry. These men, often young boys, ran through the bookshop crying out for help and were frequently slammed into the mezzanine floor, stepped on, handcuffed, arrested and dragged out of the shop to face criminal charges.
properties.I confirm that I am over the age of 18 a: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.location: Valley Fair Shopping Center now known as Westfield Mall, near the Macy's entrance on Steven's Creek Blvd.
properties.bio url: Parthenia M. Hicks, M. Div in Kriya Yoga, Los Gatos Poet Laureate Emerita, is the recipient of the Silicon Valley Arts Fellowship for Literature; the Robinson Jeffers Tor House Poetry Prize; the Villa Montalvo Biennial Poetry Prize, the Dragonfly Press Award, and Pushcart nominations for poetry and fiction. Her most recent publications include “Cold Mountain Review” and “Red Wheelbarrow.” A resident of San Jose since 1972,  she currently shares her space with her Burmese and Egyptian wild cats, Shiloh Rose and Citrine Moonbeam, who assist Parthenia as she works on her forthcoming manuscripts, One Night She Swallowed the Moon and Praying in the Women’s Bathroom.
properties.text submission:
Peacock

Just ask any legitimate bookseller. To that person, the job isn’t “retail,” it’s a choice to stay up close and personal with physical books. Physical books—the kind we sit with, open, sometimes feel unbearable pain when the spine is broken. Those people. They work in City Lights; Shakespeare and Company; Powell’s; The Strand—inside walls that contain more than forays into the highlights of literary genre. Yes, joy visits in the shape of famous and not-so-famous writers who sign books, stay for coffee or wine with the staff. These secret moments when we feel connected to the vessel that brings the words that move us, shake us up, soothe us, tear us apart, remind us of something we’d rather forget or urge us forward. Sure, those are the perks, but they’re nothing compared to the incandescent moments that happen behind the scenes, exploding quietly, away from sales, displays, bestsellers, “great” literature. The stories that surprise, imprint on the brain, make a lasting groove. The Shirley Jackson or Octavia E. Butler moments. 
The flat sound of a register reading a title. The punch of the price. The crinkling paper bag that swallows its prey. The flat thud of a body hitting the mezzanine floor of the bookshop. The skinny, threadlike sound arising from the silken throat of a young gay man, trapped, held down, terrified. The sound that lifts like a sparrow in flight, that hits the ceiling, floats, lands inside each customer who waits in line to purchase a prized volume. A bird fluttering, butting up against the heart wall, trapped, fighting with all its might to escape. We know this moment.
The cashier makes small talk with customers while the young man, in the glory of his alluring worked-out musculature, his protein shakes and club-danced body writhes in fear. In this moment, the boy is a peacock, a lavish and tender bird, an emerald translucent messenger, calling out in flight, reaching, but catching only air in his feathered grasp, trapped. His predator, cloaked in the uniform of justice, wears a badge. Police, dressed in tight t-shirts and bulging jeans hide in the Valley Fair men’s bathroom, “setting up” gay men. Officers who speak the briny lie that tortures, drags down the queens with such satisfaction. Slam a boy’s head on the landing, step on his pride, but never confess to that one hot kiss and the thrill of handcuffing his prey.
Saturday night the young man dances wildly, flashing his youth, his precious stamina, his holiness at the Crystal, the Savoy, Renegades, the Toyon. All around him sexy love blazes, but the one guilty of being himself cannot remember this in his holding cell where incessant terror spits at him, hollows him out like termites in wood. 
The cashier takes a break. Sits quietly in the backroom taking small bites of something. It’s the night shift even when it isn’t. The woman’s panties left on the bottom shelf in Fiction; the dead bird smashed inside the picture book of birds; the man who purchases the new book on the Pleiades that he believes to be the source of the voices that follow him home each night; the vision of Lois floating down the steps inquiring about a job, lost blue soul about to die on the freeway. 
One morning the bulldozer arrives, ready to bite into the bookshop. Take the lid off. It’s okay. We’ve already celebrated the dire and the profound, downstairs below ground level where the great wall of books were received, where we went to tell our stories. The tunnel behind the backroom area will be filled in with giant rocks. There will be air pockets, space to hold the words we’ll leave behind. We use spray paint, magic markers, pencils, hammers to mark our sentiments, to say our holy goodbyes. Something is leaving us, but will still have room to breathe underneath the upscale mall that will rise like a bloated white whale over the same spot where Toni Morrison, Margaret Atwood, Michael Ondaatje have lived, their voices fire rushing through trees. We write poems to Lois, to all the beautiful young men who were captured—so great was their aura—and to the broken, diseased and lost who called upon us. To the joyous who projected their love onto us. To the woman who called at 6 a.m. asking us to save her kittens. To all those who assumed we could we rise to any occasion. Powerless though we were.

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement: I often write in short forms—prose poems, flash fiction, lyric essay—forms usually less than 750 words. Specific concrete image is central  to my work. I try to be aware of the sensory world around me, and I keep a small journal for note-taking wherever I go to record compelling observations, things that catch my attention. Also, I have a particular affinity for modes of travel, for airplanes, cars, and especially trains, the no-place places of liminal time and space that enlarge my imagination. I wrote “Missed Train” as a haibun, a traditional Japanese form that pairs prose with haiku via an associative leap. The prose poem portion recalls a typical street scene near San Jose State University where I taught for over ten years—typical until the pandemic closed the campus. The haiku reinforms the memory with an image and observation  from the perspective of our new abnormal and repurposes a quote from a well-known modernist poem, another era of significant societal shock and dislocation. While “Missed Train” looks back at the before-times, the disjunctive nature of the haiku’s post-pandemic lens on a lost world, as well as the double meaning in the poem’s title, frames this San Jose story a Covid Chronicle.

properties.location: Paseo de San Antonio, San Jose, CA
properties.bio url: Sally Ashton, MFA, is a poet, writer, teacher, and editor-in-chief of DMQ Review, an online journal featuring poetry and art. She is the author of four books. The most recent, The Behaviour of Clocks (WordFarm 2019), is a poetic inquiry into time framed by Einstein’s thought experiments. Honors include fellowships from Arts Council Silicon Valley and the Lucas Artists Program at Montalvo Arts Center, and she served as the Santa Clara County Poet Laureate, 2011-2013. She has taught at SJSU, UC Santa Cruz extension, and at local and international workshops and was Visiting Poet for Fall 2020 semester in the SJSU MFA program. More info can be found at sallyashton.com
properties.text submission:
Missed Train


After class, the paseo swarms with students and their appointments with tea, coffee, all sorts of smoke. They cluster around small tables set out in front of three competing cafés that line the promenade. Farther down, a garbage can lies overturned, trash scattered. Maybe the aluminum can guy was searching again. A man speeds by on his motorized wheelchair, the aged Chihuahua crouched between his feet yapping and lunging at each passing skateboard. Another fellow shakes a paper coffee cup at a driver’s window stopped at the crosswalk where I hurry past, headed to the light rail stop dragging my wheeled backpack full of papers to grade. It grumbles against the fake cobble pressed into the pavement. Across the street, an itinerant preacher in his twenties stands on a low wall. He grasps the neck of his red electric guitar strung over a shoulder, the other hand holding an open book aloft, loudly rehearsing a sermon to no one visible. People wait for a bus near the platform where I too will have to wait for the next train. The one I just missed clangs down the street, wheels whining around the corner. Just far enough back from the smoke-free zone to be legal, people light up. When a bus pulls to the curb, the doors let off some kid wearing a black beanie studded with multi-colored buttons. He produces a ukulele from his backpack as if that’s why he came here, as if that’s what we are all waiting for. He leans against a light pole and strums a calliope-like melody for everyone, the preacher, a child now crying in its stroller, her tired mother, the departing bus’ roar, and far down the tracks, its headlight just appearing, the next train.



Words left on paper.
The apparitions linger—
faces in a crowd

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement:
Useless Phrases is a social art project that attempts to ease the burden of the useless, hurtful, or abusive phrases that we carry with us through our lives. Using geocoding, anonymously collected “useless phrases” are placed back into their location of origin. Geocoding will allow viewers to see and interact with the phrases that have been placed back to their original location.
Oftentimes the words we carry with us are surprisingly more mundane than we might think. Useless Phrases welcomes any and all phrases that participants wish to let go of. While we hope this project brings more awareness to verbal and domestic abuse and the significance of its harmful effects on us as individuals, Useless Phrases is not limited to abusive language. Some of these useless phrases can be spoken by parents, partners, or ourselves and may seem minimal in comparison to others. However we can not compare our pain, and healing thrives in authenticity. So please send us your individual and honest useless phrase. While using geocoding won’t erase these phrases it will hopefully ease the burden of carrying them with us on a daily basis.

Katharine T, Jacobs and Ian G. Fabre have combined their strengths and weaknesses to create an engaging social art project that attempts to heal and inform. 
Jacobs and Fabre have come to find through their unique life experiences and individual trauma that they are inspired by a shared interest in helping others and a desire for personal growth which has led to the technological birth the concept and experience of Useless Phrases.

properties.bio url:
Katharine T. Jacobs is an interdisciplinary fine artist. She received her BFA in photography from Oregon College of Art and Craft in 2010 and is currently obtaining an MFA in photography from San Jose State University. Her background in craft has instilled a deep passion for historical practices, fine construction and conceptual art. While photography is a focus, Katharine’s work has never been limited to that particular medium. She often incorporates text, objects, stitching, and soft sculpture into her series and installations. 

Katharine in an award winning artist and a seasoned arts educator with a passion for accessibility in art and education. Her teaching and art practices have always intertwined as she pulls inspiration and insight from her students. As an intersectional feminist artist, she aims to find new ways that art and education can be more accessible, approachable and inclusive.

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement:
from: Irene
to: You

I am from my breath
Breathe in, breathe out
With every inhale the memory comes closer
With every exhale it recedes a little

Breathe in, 
the vanilla of the toritos blooming
the musty heavy air of the rainy season
the honeysuckle outside my window
my baby’s sweaty skin when I come to nurse him 
Write them all down before you exhale, before you

breathe out and they are all gone.

I am from my mouth, 
that entrance into my body that has allowed 
nutrients in, laughter out 
What tastes remain in my mouth’s memory? 
What memory make my mouth water or my lips pucker?

I am from the taste of gallo pinto, 
acacia honey, cas and cacao
I am from 
bitter swallowed words
Sweet laughter
Spicy passion
Salty tears and sweat


I am from my ears
Ears that often hear too much and 
often don’t hear enough
Selective hearing 
Do they hear or do they listen?
I wish to listen
I wish to listen and understand
The chirping of the cicadas of my childhood, 
the rhythm of the waves, 
ancestral stories specially told by my grandmother, Tetei.


I am from, what some might call, a banana republic
from a small house close to the railroad tracks
from a singer sewing machine, 
a book shelf made of cinder blocks and planks of 
splintery wood, 
a vinyl tablecloth 
But mostly 
I am from the universe inside me where the history, 
the secrets, pain, happiness and dreams reside.

properties.bio url:
Irene Carvajal is a multidisciplinary Costa Rican-American artist, her art practice includes printmaking, collage, sculpture, video, performance and installation. Thematically her work touches on the intersectionality of colonialism, labor, feminism, value, mass production and environmentalism. She is an experimental, conceptual artist interested in materiality and meaning making through process and medium. Her research has lead her to explore sustainable alternatives to traditional methods and materials.

Irene has exhibited in the United States, Japan and Costa Rica. She received her BFA from the University of Kansas and her MFA at SFAI where she received the Bronze Roller Award. She is the recipient of multiple awards and grants for the arts and arts education. She has taught at several universities including Stanford, SFAI (where she served as chair of the printmaking department) and SJSU. She has participated in art residencies in Japan, USA, Mexico and Costa Rica. Most recently at La Ceiba Gráfica in Vera Cruz, Mexico.

Currently, she lectures at San Jose State University.

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement:
I keep wanting to write a light little novel or story series that brings joy to the world without bringing anguish to me. So far, that has evaded me because all my frothy little pieces turn into much deeper work when I expand them.
But this little mystery series--perhaps I could call it “flash mysteries”?--may finally accomplish that lighter purpose. I love San Jose and the tremendous variety of cool people who make it the hidden treasure it is. That’s why I gave my protagonist a multi-ethnic identity using surnames one can easily find in San Jose. I’ve long wanted to set a mystery series here, looking at our quirks and foibles (in a mostly loving way) and our gifts and talents while promoting laughter and hope. I also teach creative writing at De Anza and CreatorSchoolCA.com and private workshops where I've met so many creative San Joseans (Is that the name for San Jose residents?)

properties.title of work: Lydia Rotini Hernandez-Nguyen, Specialist in Tiny Crimes
properties.bio url: Lita Kurth  MFA- Rainier Writers Workshop, has published in three genres, fiction, creative nonfiction, and poetry. “Are We Not Ladies,” was nominated by Watershed Review for Best of the Net, 2017 and “Fish Genesis” was nominated by Rabid Oak for Best of the Net, 2019. “This is the Way We Wash the Clothes,” (CNF) won the 2014 Diana Woods Memorial Award (Lunchticket). Her creative nonfiction “Pivot,” and short story, "Gardener's Delight" (Dragonfly Press DNA) were nominated for Pushcart Prizes.  She is co-founder of San Jose’s literary reading series, Flash Fiction Forum and will teach a class for in-progress novelists and memoirists for CreatorSchoolCA.com this June called “The Messy Middle.”
properties.text submission:
Excerpt from the first installment in a San Jose Mystery Series: Lydia Rotini Hernandez-Nguyen, Specialist in Tiny Crimes by Lita Kurth
       Lydia Rotini’s cell phone buzzed, and although her lunch break was not quite over, the thought of human suffering made her swallow the last bite of banh mi sandwich, clear her throat, and answer, “Lydia Rotini Hernandez-Nguyen, Specialist in Tiny Crimes throughout the greater San Jose area.”
      The woman on the other end could scarcely speak through her sobs. “A terrible crime has been committed in Willow Glen. Please I need your help.”
      Lydia was unsurprised. Willow Glen was a seething cauldron of small crime. Soothingly, she asked for the address, and after doublechecking that her best camera and crime scene tools were packed into her colorful Laurel Birch bag, she headed out to an address on Camino Palomino. When she reached the enormous fenced chateau, a big cardboard box stood in front of its locked iron gate, and she had to reach over it to ring the bell.
      Soon enough, a stylish older woman hurried down the walkway worry written all over her face in capital letters. “Are you Lydia?”
      “I am, madam,” Lydia said in comforting tones.
      “This morning I opened my gate to something I hope I never see again. I still can’t believe it happened. Someone dumped a bucket of dead leaves right in front of my gate!”
      Lydia’s brow furrowed. “Oh dear. I’m very sorry to hear that.”
      “I preserved the evidence,” the woman said and lifted the cardboard box.
 Immediately Lydia could see why the woman had said it was a bucket of dead leaves because this leaves were wet and held the shape of a bucket very clearly. Lydia regarded her gravely. “You’ve shown tremendous presence of mind. Sometimes in the midst of trauma, people unthinkingly destroy evidence.”
      The woman's blue eyes brimmed with tears. “Can you believe the police wouldn’t come for this?”
      “I can believe it, madam,” Lydia said, “but I cannot condone it. I shall endeavor to get to the bottom of this as well as the middle and the top. “
She surveyed the crime scene, “After I’ve done my initial physical investigation, I shall need to ask you some questions.”
      “Just ring the bell when you’ve finished, and I’ll let you into the house.” The woman dabbed the tears from her cheeks with a linen handkerchief. “And thank you.”
      Quietly pleased to be of service to the suffering, Lydia bent down with her tape measure and measured the top and bottom diameters of the dead leaf pile as well as its height. She photographed it from every angle and put on latex gloves to take a sample. Since it was November, they were particularly beautiful leaves which Lydia recognized as Chinese pistache. She picked up the leaf, sniffed it and recorded the odor: nutlike and autumny, with an earthy undertone. She crinkled one in her hand, then put it in a plastic ziplock bag.
When Lydia entered the chateau, the woman had laid out tea on a lovely trolley. Beside the teacups and exquisite Japanese teapot was a lace doily and on the doiley sat a bone china plate and on the plate sat several croissants that smelled exquisite.
      “How could someone do such a thing?” The woman asked in a heartbroken voice, adding “Cream and sugar?”
      “About a fourth cup of cream, thank you,” Lydia said. “No sugar.” She took a sip of tea. My but it was excellent. She looked toward the distant other side of the room and said somberly,       “I, a mere detective,  cannot pretend to plumb the depths of evil and madness that I encounter daily in San Jose. How could I? Philosophers and theologians have contemplated these questions for centuries and have not come to agreement. CONTACT LITA FOR THE CONCLUSION!

properties.bio url:
Kevin is a transplanted Midwesterner from Barrington, Illinois who’s lived in Palo Alto, California most of his life. He has published in fifty literary magazines and has published a book of poems and a novel.
     	He served as President, Poetry Center San Jose, for twelve years, while he earned an MFA from San Jose State University. The San Francisco/Peninsula California Writer’s Club recently named him Writer of the Year. His novel, The Sureness of Horses, available in hardback, softcover, soft copy, and as an audiobook read by Sands Hall from Cherry Hill Publications.

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement: I grew up in Almaden Valley. My father still lives in the house I grew up in. These poems are rooted not only in San Jose but in my father's two explosive marriages. Mental illness. Homophobia. All those things I didn't initially have language for until I discovered the possibilities of what poetry could do. It was my meal ticket out of there.

properties.bio url: Timothy Liu is the author of twelve books of poems and Editor-in-Chief at Saturnalia Books.  A native of San Jose, he is a reader of occult esoterica and divides his time between Manhattan and Woodstock, NY.
properties.text submission:
Thoreau


My father and I have no place to go.
His wife will not let us in the house—
afraid of catching AIDS. She thinks
sleeping with men is more than a sin,
my father says, as we sit on the curb
in front of someone else’s house.
Sixty-four years have made my father
impotent. Silver roots, faded black
dye mottling his hair make him look
almost comical, as if his shame
belonged to me. Last night we read
Thoreau in a steak house down the road
and wept: If a man does not keep pace
with his companions, let him travel
to the music that he hears, however
measured or far away. The orchards
are gone, his village near Shanghai
bombed by the Japanese, the groves
I have known in Almaden—apricot,
walnut, peach and plum—hacked down.



	 
Canker


The wound would not heal for days. But that was nothing compared to my mother who ran her mouth all over my body.

What people will do to be remembered.

The nurses cutting roses from the cards I sent have put them in a tub of scalding water. The kisses have come undone.

Stamps are all she can save, arranging them in a book like all the photographs she could never take.

I have managed to piece together the pages she tore away from me. Though the box of letters burned, the ashes were not entirely extinguished.

The day after Christmas break, my father was driving me back to school, the two-lane highway on fire, everything falling. 

To me, their divorce was never final, only a precarious extension, a bridge I had learned to walk between two cliffs.

I remember blood on the dining-room floor and a few drops down his cheek when I broke a chair over his back. It wasn’t damaged beyond repair, but it was put away in the attic.

And I thought, if only Mother knew. The county had already locked her up for the first time that year: her neighbors had complained about sacks of garbage she threw from her balcony into the swimming pool below.

I still can hear her voice that day in junior high when I was called out of class. She said to me in the backseat,

Love me, let me die,

her head bobbing in my lap, floating in its pool of chemicals. The woman who couldn’t get in to clean drove us to the emergency room.

Let me die.

That’s all I heard when I broke into her bedroom, the pills scattered on the floor like a broken necklace.

She lived. That night there was a canker in the back of my throat. I couldn’t eat for days. My father opened cans of a protein drink he’d brought home from the hospital.

Drink this. Now sleep. Good.

That was the first time I remember being held. I told my father at the end of our trip. I told him about the men who came into my life. The pain that made me feel alive.

My father wept as we swerved to the side of the road. Then he began to speak, stoking a bed of ashes that years could not put out:

Your aunt wrote me while you had stayed with them, still a baby. You’d scream if your mother came into the room where you were being bathed. Her sister told her not to touch you but she did.

I wanted this to stop. Why couldn’t anyone stop her?

There are no photographs of you then. She wouldn’t have them in the house reminding her.

My mother entered me with a kiss.

At Easter break, I flew on a half-empty plane into the eye of night. I didn’t bring her flowers, though I thought of how they would look on a grave.

I wanted her in the earth, her body contained.

Not floating down a river of fire. Not knowing the words she said to me that night would burn:

Your father lies. Please God, don’t hurt your mother. You were always so difficult, crying, crying. I couldn’t shut you up. You didn’t want my milk. Only your father. How could I live with myself?

After we cried, I put out the light. I left her in that room. I closed the door behind me. 

Tonight my roses bloom beside her bed, working their thorns into her lips, the words I never knew how to say:

Mother, nothing heals completely as long as I stay alive.

properties.terms: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.statement:
I AM FROM: Lucia Znamirowski

I am from the smell of breath. Language, speech, pain raved in me from the galactic presence that protects us. What is spoken, pronounced, tends to be consumed. 

I am from the taste of East Poland. I felt thankful after meals, so I couldn’t believe in god. If not for the aversion to the smell of wine or blood, I could think I was a good woman.

I am from the sound of reading ancient authors. Feeding cats in the street.  For this is the only way to forget having to know myself.

I am from a memory.  Not to know. A landscape raw with curses, building upon what came before. Evidence, the light unyielding.
properties.I confirm that I am over the age of 18 a: I have read and agree to the terms and conditions.
properties.bio url: Lucia Znamirowski (born 1985) is an American interdisciplinary artist. Znamirowski is an MFA Candidate at San Jose State University in San Jose, California.  A former artist in resident at Kala Art Institute (2010) currently working as a project manager on San Jose Story Maps Project with artist, Rhonda Holberton.  Znamirowski is moved by ideas of memory, time, and change. She is known for her installations of DIY materials, drawings of women and animals, often executed with strong black and white contrasts.  Always building upon what came before, she continually re-visits her compositions, re-creating them in an attempt to copy them, while understanding the impossibility of this pursuit. She chases these ever changing differences between each art work as proof of our constantly shifting existence.
